bibl.title: Notes from Liberian Legation In U.S. to Department of State, 1862-1898 T807

body.div1:
Memorandum of the Liberian Government on the Anglo-French Agreement concerning the delimitation of their respective boundraies on the West Coast of Africa and the Soudan**.
The Liberian Government having been made cognisant of the said agreement, submits the following propositions thereon:
Considering that the districts commprising its south eastern territory situated between Cape Palmas and the San Pedro River were included within the limits of the State of Maryland in Liberia as far back as the years 1835-50, and that no counter claime was set up at that time by any European State.
Considering also that the State of Maryland in Liberia was peacefully incorporated with the Republic of Liberia in the year 1854, that said uicorporation* was then and there published to the world, and that no protest against it was made by any European State, that therefore said uicorporation* has had thr santion and acknowledgement of the civilized world for nearly half a century and that it is only within the last six years that
any
any claim to said territory have seen preferred by the Government of France.
Considering also that these territories are responsible for a portion of the Foreign debt of the Republic.
Considering also that Ameries* Liberian nuiuous* and schools have in the past and are at present established in they said districts and up the Cavalla River.
Considering also that the Map of Africa precisely published by the Royal Geographical Soverign of Belgium shows, the proposed interior boundray of the Republic at its greatest width at Roporo, in the Condo country, which would only give the Republic an interior extent of about 40 miles; and that the whole of the Condo Country was formally ceded to the Republic by King Momonu how in the year 1868-69
Considering also that the countries between Monrovia* and the interior slope of the Western Mandings plateau were explored by Benjamin Anderson at the instance of the Liberian Government during the years 1868, 1873, and 1874 and confirmed to the Republic by Special Treaties, and are now set down in
the
the French map of that region as unexplored and therefore liable become a prosectorate* of France.
Cosidering also that the present or prospection delimitation according to the Map referred to, would cut off or separate from the Republic of all access to the River Niger, contray to the Winterland* doctrine now acknowledged in, Europe as binding with respect to European acquistions on the African Continent.
Considering also, that the Republic of Liberia is not a European State but was an Independent, African Government in existence long before the era of the Berlin Conference and was in possession of said territory at a period considerably interior to the conveying of said Conference, and was not invited to participate in its deliberations, and ought not therefore to be bound by the rules there at preseriled* for the conduct of European Powers in Africa, and that the Republic seeks only that territory which has, for so long at period been acknowledged to
rightfully
rightfully belong to her,and the right of her Winterland.*
For the above reasons the Republic considers that her boundraies ought in all right and justtice to extend form the Mannah River, on the South to the San Pedro River on the South, and inferior wars from the Sea coast to the River Niger in accordance with the Riterland* law. This, regulation of her boundraies would be of very little moment to the European States who have acquired such extensive Empires in Africa, but is of vital importance to the Republic of Liberia, and would further more sufficently meet her just aspirations.
The Republic therefore protest against the conclusion of the said Agreement, so far as the deprivation of Liberian territory by France is concerned, and solicits the good offices of the United States Government to overt his impendening loss of territory on her sea board and interior.
E.T.Beverly* Monrovia May 6, 1891
